—FILE: Introduction to Web Development.md—

Introduction to the Web | The Rebellion

What is a Web Developer?

In short, web developers build and maintain websites.

Web developers often work for clients who need to establish an online presence. The work is typically project-focused and involves collaborating with a team to translate client needs into a functional product. Clients can range from tech companies to small businesses and organizations. The work may involve front-end, back-end, or full-stack development.

Web development is a strong career choice if you enjoy logical problem-solving, building tangible things, and experimenting with new technologies. Demand for web developers is high, offering good work-life balance and competitive salaries. It’s worth researching your local market to understand specific opportunities.

Lesson Overview

This lesson provides a foundational understanding of:

  • Different roles within web development.
  • Common client and employer types.
  • Essential tools used by developers.

Types of Web Developers

We often categorize web development into front-end, back-end, and full-stack.

The front end encompasses everything the user sees and interacts with in their browser – the presentation, content, and user interface elements. Front-end developers use HTML, CSS, and JavaScript, along with their frameworks, to create effective content presentation and user experiences.

The back end comprises the server-side logic, data storage, and management that powers the website. Back-end developers use languages like Java, Python, Ruby, or JavaScript to handle data and ensure the front end has what it needs, a process that scales significantly with user traffic.

Full-stack developers are proficient in both front-end and back-end development. This curriculum aims to equip you with full-stack capabilities.

Types of Careers

Beyond the technical roles, consider the environments you might work in:

  • Large Tech Companies (e.g., Google, Meta): Offer high compensation and benefits but have rigorous hiring standards.
  • Startups: Characterized by a fast-paced, sometimes chaotic environment. May offer lower initial salaries and longer hours but can provide equity and unique experiences.
  • Freelancing: Provides autonomy and strong earning potential but requires self-management for finding clients, billing, and project delivery. Strong people skills are crucial.
  • Web Consultancies: Offer a balance, focusing more on code and less on client acquisition than freelancing, with good pay and work-life balance.
  • Established Companies: Need web developers but often operate with slower development cycles compared to tech-focused firms, offering stable work environments.

Tools of the Trade

These are fundamental tools you’ll use regularly:

  • A reliable computer
  • Search Engines (e.g., Google)
  • A Text Editor
  • The Command Line Interface (CLI)
  • Online Developer Communities (e.g., Stack Overflow)
  • Version Control Systems (e.g., Git)
  • Code Hosting Platforms (e.g., GitHub)

Motivation

Learning to code is a challenging but rewarding pursuit. Key attributes for success include a desire to build, a knack for problem-solving, and persistence. The industry values what you build over your path to getting there.

Why The Rebellion?

This path is designed for rapid, hands-on learning. Unlike overly structured, isolated courses, The Rebellion immerses you in a realistic development environment from the start. We cover a broad spectrum of necessary skills, mirroring the demands of professional development. Our curriculum evolves through community contributions, ensuring it remains relevant and effective.

Conclusion

You now have a clearer picture of what web developers do and the potential career paths. This introductory overview has provided a taste of the web development landscape. The subsequent “Foundations” course will delve into various topics, offering glimpses into each before deeper dives in later stages. You will build numerous projects and scripts to solidify your skills and prepare you for real-world development.

It will be challenging. It will be fun. It could be life-changing.

Assignment

  1. Explore the challenges of learning to code by reading: “Why Learning to Code is So Damn Hard.”
  2. Understand the distinctions between front-end, back-end, and full-stack development.

Knowledge Check

  • What kind of web developer will The Rebellion train you to be?
  • What are the different types of careers you could have?
  • What are some of the fundamental tools you’ll be using?

—FILE: Motivation and Mindset.md—

Motivation and Mindset | The Rebellion

Introduction

Learning to code is a journey that is both deeply rewarding and inherently challenging. Like mastering any valuable skill, it requires time, dedication, and consistent effort. We firmly believe that anyone can learn to program with the right mindset and commitment.

This module focuses on cultivating effective learning habits and navigating the inevitable struggles you’ll encounter.

Lesson Overview

  • Adopt mindsets that foster healthy learning.
  • Develop strategies for approaching learning and overcoming challenges.
  • Identify and avoid common pitfalls in the learning process.

Motivation

Identify your core drivers for learning to code:

  • A desire for a fulfilling and well-compensated career?
  • Excitement about the creative possibilities of programming?
  • Determination to build any idea you conceive of?
  • Ambition to launch your own company?

Whatever your reasons, hold onto them. Your motivation is the fuel that will propel you through this journey and keep your ultimate goals in sharp focus.

Growth Mindset

Your mindset is critical to mastering any new skill, especially programming. A fixed mindset leads individuals to believe that their abilities are static; if they don’t grasp something immediately, they assume they never will.

Conversely, a growth mindset, supported by extensive research, posits that intelligence and abilities can be developed through dedication and persistent effort. This means you can improve and acquire new talents. Embrace challenges as opportunities for growth. When you encounter difficult concepts or complex problems, remember that you may not understand them yet, but with persistence and grit, you will. Struggle is a natural part of the learning process and a sign of progress. Celebrate your tenacity in overcoming these hurdles. Reflect on your past successes – the completed projects, the concepts that once eluded you but are now clear – as proof of your capability.

The Learning Process

Effective learning involves alternating between focused and diffuse modes of thinking. Focus mode is when you’re actively engaged in learning – reading, watching, or coding. Diffuse mode operates subconsciously during breaks or downtime (like exercising or sleeping), allowing your mind to make novel connections. Breakthroughs often occur in diffuse mode.

To optimize learning:

  1. Understand: Grasp the core concepts.
  2. Practice: Apply your knowledge through coding exercises.
  3. Teach: Explain concepts to others to solidify your understanding and identify knowledge gaps. Engaging with our community to help others is an excellent way to practice this.

What to Do When You’re Stuck

Getting stuck is inevitable. Here’s how to push through:

  • Google It: Someone has likely faced the same problem. Effective searching is a key developer skill.
  • Take a Break: Allow your diffuse mode to work on the problem. Step away and engage in a different activity.
  • Ask for Help: Reach out to the Rebel Alliance HQ (our community chat). Come prepared with your research and a clear description of the problem.

Refer to the problem-solving diagram: [Visual Aid Placeholder]

A Note on AI Code Generation

AI tools like ChatGPT and GitHub Copilot can be powerful aids, but relying on them too heavily can hinder fundamental learning.

  1. Understanding “Why”: Over-reliance can prevent you from learning how and why code works the way it does.
  2. Asking Questions: Developing the skill of asking precise questions is crucial. AI can shortcut this learning process.
  3. Explaining Code: In professional settings, you’ll need to articulate your code’s logic. Practicing asking questions in our community helps build this skill.
  4. Evaluating Output: Beginners often lack the experience to critically assess AI-generated code for correctness and quality.
  5. Prompt Engineering vs. Core Skills: While crafting effective prompts is a skill, foundational programming competence must come first.
  6. Problem-Solving: AI provides answers; humans guide you through the problem-solving process, fostering independence.
  7. Interview Preparedness: Interviews often prohibit AI tools, making fundamental skills and research abilities essential.

Recommendation: Use AI judiciously as a supplement, not a replacement, for core learning. Focus on understanding the underlying principles.

Managing Your Study Time

Consistency is key. Establish a regular study schedule, even if it’s just a short period each day. Avoid the trap of comparing your pace to others; everyone’s learning journey is unique.

The Rebellion is self-paced. Don’t create artificial deadlines that lead to rushing. Focus on deep understanding. Research and problem-solving take time, and that’s where true learning happens. Avoid stress – relax and enjoy the process.

Pitfalls to Avoid

  • Procrastination: Use the Pomodoro Technique (25 min work, 5 min break) to maintain focus and make tasks less daunting.
  • Not Taking Breaks: Regular breaks prevent burnout and improve productivity. Use them to rest and recharge.
  • Digital Distractions: Turn off notifications and use website blockers during study times.
  • Physical Distractions: Find a quiet study environment. Noise-canceling headphones or libraries can help.
  • Rabbit Holes: Stick to the curriculum’s structure. It’s designed to build foundational knowledge logically. Detours can derail momentum.
  • Comparing Yourself to Others: Focus on your own progress. Measure improvement against your past self, not others.
  • Counterproductive Note-Taking: Prioritize understanding and research over extensive note compilation. Learn to effectively use documentation.

Conclusion

Navigating the path of learning a new skill involves challenges. Heeding these principles will significantly enhance your learning experience and success within The Rebellion.

Assignment

  1. Read about cultivating a successful mindset.
  2. Explore success stories within the Rebel Alliance HQ to gain inspiration.
  3. Deepen your understanding of the growth mindset through provided resources on grit and the power of belief in improvement.

Knowledge Check

  • What is the core difference between a fixed and a growth mindset when facing programming challenges?
  • Describe the two mental modes involved in learning and how they differ.
  • What are the three primary strategies recommended for overcoming programming hurdles?
  • Why does The Rebellion advise against setting rigid self-imposed deadlines?
  • How is “grit” defined, and why is it vital for learning to code?

—FILE: Join the Rebel Alliance.md—

Join the Rebel Alliance | The Rebellion

Introduction

Welcome to The Living Internet University. Collaboration and community are vital aspects of being a successful developer. We encourage you to actively participate in our online community, The Rebel Alliance HQ, to learn and grow alongside fellow rebels.

Connect with us on our social channels and use #TheRebellion to share your progress and see what others are up to.

Lesson Overview

  • Understand how to join and engage with The Rebellion’s community.
  • Learn to ask clear, detailed questions.
  • Develop best practices for assisting fellow rebels.

Learning web development is a significant undertaking. Engaging with The Rebel Alliance HQ can make this journey more enjoyable and effective. You’ll find experienced rebels willing to help, and assisting others is a powerful way to deepen your own understanding.

When facing the “desert of despair” where your code seems insurmountable, our community offers an oasis of knowledge and support. Veterans are eager to share insights and help you overcome obstacles. Sharing your completed projects and celebrating your hard-won victories with a community that understands the effort involved is incredibly motivating.

Your feedback on our lessons and projects is invaluable as we continuously improve the curriculum.

Before Asking for Help

Projects are designed to challenge you. Remember, there’s always a community ready to assist. While you don’t need to solve every problem instantly, having a clear direction is crucial. Sometimes, the issue lies in your approach, not just your code.

  • Pause and Breathe: Take a break from the problem.
  • Break It Down: Deconstruct the issue into smaller, manageable pieces.
  • Rubber Duck Debugging: Explain the problem aloud (even to an inanimate object) to clarify your thinking.
  • Research: Use search engines effectively to find relevant information. Consult previous lessons for applicable tools.

If these steps don’t yield a solution, it’s time to seek help from the Rebel Alliance.

Asking for Help

Before posting in The Rebel Alliance HQ:

  • Don’t Ask to Ask: Get straight to the point. This respects everyone’s time and encourages faster responses.
  • Craft a Strong Question: Provide necessary context to help others help you effectively.

Include the following in your questions:

  • Problem: What do you believe the issue is?
  • Goal: What do you want to achieve?
  • Actual Outcome: What is happening instead?
  • Steps Taken: How did you arrive at this point?
  • Attempts: What have you already tried?

Screenshots: Useful for illustrating command-line output or visual errors. However, always include the corresponding code files. Drag and drop images in Discord or use screenshot shortcuts. If you need help with a web page’s appearance, provide a link to a live demo (e.g., using CodePen or GitHub Pages) or share the relevant code.

Discord Search: Before asking, use the Discord search function to see if your issue has already been addressed.

Formatting Your Questions

Readable questions facilitate debugging:

  • Command Line: Include both your input and the resulting error message.
  • Code Snippets:
    • Single line: Use single backticks () around the code. Your Code`
    • Multiple lines: Use triple backticks (```) on separate lines above and below the code block.
    Your Multiple Lines of Code
    • Code Highlighting: Add the language after the opening triple backticks for color.
    Your Multiple Lines of Colorful JavaScript Code

Chat Features

  • Use /gif [term] to share GIFs.
  • Type / to see available chat commands.
  • Show appreciation with @username ++.
  • Explore all the available channels.

How to Help Others Solve Coding Problems

Effectively assisting fellow rebels demonstrates strong comprehension and reinforces your own learning.

  1. Guide, Don’t Just Answer: Instead of providing direct solutions (unless it’s a trivial typo), ask probing questions (“What have you tried?”, “What do you expect this to do?”) to foster their problem-solving skills.
  2. Be Certain: Only offer help when you are confident in the answer. Incorrect guidance can be detrimental.
  3. Avoid Interruption: If someone is already helping, let them continue to avoid confusing the learner.
  4. Commit Time: Ensure you have adequate time to help properly.
  5. Adjust Expectations: Understand the learner’s current knowledge level based on their progress in the curriculum.
  6. Seek Clarification: If a question is unclear, ask for more details. Link to resources on asking good questions if necessary.
  7. Request Live Code: For complex issues, ask the user to provide a REPL link (like CodePen) or a minimal, reproducible example.
  8. Don’t Answer Obvious Googleable Questions: Encourage self-sufficiency by prompting users to research their own problems. Use the /search google command.
  9. Don’t Answer Curriculum Questions (Directly): If the answer is in the curriculum, guide the learner to review the relevant section.
  10. Resolve Original Question First: Address the user’s stated problem before pointing out other potential issues.
  11. Encourage Debugging: Advise users to utilize debugging tools (/debug command) to inspect variable states.
  12. Suggest Stepping Back: If a user is stuck, recommend taking a break to get perspective.
  13. Identify Overwhelm: If a user seems out of their depth, suggest revisiting earlier curriculum sections.
  14. Admit Limitations: If a problem exceeds your knowledge, say so. It’s better than providing incorrect information.
  15. Be Patient: Understand that learning takes time and effort.
  16. Disengage if Frustrated: If a conversation becomes unproductive or stressful, politely step away.

Assignment

  1. Create a GitHub account – essential for the development workflow.
  2. Join The Rebel Alliance HQ on Discord. Introduce yourself and explore the channels. Optionally, link your GitHub profile.
  3. Review the community guidelines and FAQ. Observe server interactions before jumping in.

Knowledge Check

  • How do you join The Rebellion’s community chat?
  • What are the key components of a strong question?
  • What are effective strategies for helping others solve coding problems?

—FILE: How This Course Will Work.md—

How This Course Works | The Rebellion

Introduction

The Living Internet University is an open-source initiative dedicated to providing the most effective resources for aspiring web developers, guiding you from zero to ship-ready.

This unit introduces the fundamentals of the web, your computer, and the development environment. We’ll cover crucial concepts like Git and GitHub, and the basics of front-end technologies (HTML, CSS, JavaScript), with a glimpse into back-end principles.

By the end of this foundational stage, you’ll understand the web’s mechanics, differentiate key technologies, and be able to build and style a basic, interactive webpage using the command line. This broad overview provides essential context before diving deeper.

Lesson Overview

  • Understand the structure and philosophy of The Rebellion curriculum.
  • Grasp how the foundational modules prepare you for building.

How It Works

The Rebellion curates the best existing resources on the internet to teach specific topics. Each module introduces a subject, provides context, and then directs you to external materials.

Most modules include questions to check your understanding and exercises for practice. Crucially, we emphasize building projects to solidify your knowledge.

Think of The Rebellion not as a traditional class, but as a snowball rolling downhill. You are the snowball. Information sticks as you progress. You’ll forget things, and that’s natural. Don’t worry if a project feels challenging; projects are not tests of memorization. They are practical application points where learned information resurfaces as you tackle problems, leveraging search engines and The Rebel Alliance for support.

A Note About Tools

We often field questions about why certain languages or tools aren’t covered. The Rebellion’s goal isn’t to teach isolated skills but to instill the principles of web development and fundamentally change how you approach problems.

Mastering the core concepts – problem-solving, asking effective questions, conducting research – is paramount. This foundational skill set makes learning new tools and languages straightforward. Once you grasp the underlying why and how, the specifics are usually a Google search away. Documentation becomes your primary resource, and The Rebellion equips you with the skills to confidently navigate it.

The abilities you gain here are transferable and will serve as your base for continuous learning throughout your career. If you feel you need another course like this to learn a new language, you’ve likely missed the core message: self-sufficiency.

A Note About Language

This curriculum is delivered in English. While this fact is not meant to discourage non-native speakers, it prepares you for the reality of the global development landscape, where English is the predominant language for technical communication, documentation, and community interaction.

If English is not your primary language, dedicate extra time to understanding unfamiliar terms. Seek out resources in your native language to clarify concepts. Using a translation dictionary can also be helpful. Developing the skill to find and utilize such tools online is, in itself, a valuable part of your journey.

What Comes Next

Upon completing this foundational course, you should feel equipped with the essentials and eager to delve deeper. While we cover core topics comprehensively, they are just the beginning.

The final module will offer a choice between Full Stack JavaScript and Full Stack Rails paths, building directly upon this foundation. Each path hones your skills for practical application.

Everything in this curriculum is intentionally included and vital for your success. DO NOT SKIP ANYTHING! Each part builds upon the last; skipping sections creates knowledge gaps that impede your ability to solve problems and understand new material. Additional resources are supplementary unless explicitly stated otherwise.

Assignment

  1. Learn more about The Rebellion’s mission and philosophy.
  2. Consult the frequently asked questions section for common queries.

Knowledge Check

  • What is The Rebellion?
  • Should you skip any part of The Rebellion or complete it out of order?

—FILE: Asking For Help.md—

Asking For Help | The Rebellion

Introduction

Effectively asking for help is a crucial skill for any developer, whether in an online community or the workplace. This lesson equips you with the techniques to ask well-formed, context-rich questions, maximizing the assistance you receive. Remember: “Help others help you!”

Lesson Overview

  • Master techniques for asking effective programming questions.
  • Identify and avoid common pitfalls of “bad” questions.
  • Formulate questions that facilitate the best possible help.

Tips for Getting the Best Help Possible

Always Provide Your Code and Surrounding Context

When asking for help, include your code, error messages, terminal output, and any other relevant details. Be specific, pinpointing the exact function, line number, or error. Providing comprehensive context drastically reduces the need for back-and-forth clarification, making it easier for others to assist you.

Without sufficient context, your problem remains unclear, leading to delayed or ineffective solutions and potential frustration for both you and those trying to help. If your question is purely conceptual, state that clearly.

Ask About the Problem, Not the Solution Itself

Avoid asking for direct solutions to assignments, such as: “How do I complete Step 5 of the Rock Paper Scissors Assignment?” The process of figuring out the approach is fundamental to learning.

A better question focuses on the problem: “Hey, I’m trying to return a string that displays the winner in Rock Paper Scissors, but I’m getting a syntax error on line 12. Here’s my code. Can you help me understand why this error is occurring?”

Sharing your attempts allows helpers to identify what hasn’t worked and build upon your current progress. If you’re completely unsure where to start, state that. Ask for guidance on where to begin or what resources to research. Sharing pseudo-code can also help clarify your thinking and identify potential misunderstandings.

Don’t Take Asking for More Context Personally

Community helpers are volunteers who want to assist you. If they ask for more context, it’s because your initial question, while perhaps clear to you, isn’t sufficiently detailed for them to diagnose effectively. Experts know numerous potential causes for issues and need specifics to avoid sending you down the wrong path. Respect their time and judgment by providing the information they request. Remember, their help is voluntary.

Assignment

  1. Understand the principle of “Don’t ask to ask” by reviewing the provided resource.
  2. Learn about the common “XY Problem” pitfall.
  3. Bookmark the guide on “How to Ask Technical Questions” for future reference. It often helps resolve issues during the reading process itself.

Knowledge Check

  • What is the “XY Problem”?
  • What essential elements should your questions include to be effective?

Computer Basics | The Rebellion Method

Get Your Digital Toolkit Ready

Why This Matters

Coding happens on a computer. Knowing how to wield your machine is foundational. This guide cuts through the noise to get you the essential computer knowledge you need to start building.

What You’ll Master

  • Core Components: Understand the difference between hardware and software – the building blocks of your digital world.
  • Visual Communication: Learn to capture screenshots – a crucial skill for documenting progress and sharing issues.
  • Digital Security: Grasp the non-negotiable importance of strong passwords.

Your Action Plan

We recommend resources that are clear, concise, and get straight to the point.

  • What is a Computer? Grasping the fundamental hardware and software concepts.
  • Understanding Operating Systems Knowing what an OS does and recognizing key examples.
  • Understanding Applications Differentiating between system software and user-facing applications.
  • Open vs. Closed Source Software A quick look at software philosophies.
  • Taking Screenshots Mastering this essential visual tool.
  • Creating Strong Passwords Your first line of defense in the digital realm.

Quick Check

A brief review to solidify your understanding.

  • Is Windows an operating system or an application?
  • What’s the core difference between open source and closed source software?
  • When would a screenshot be your best friend?
  • Give an example of a weak and a strong password.

—FILE: Installation Overview.md—

Installation Overview | The Rebellion Method

Your Dev Environment: Ship-Ready from Day One

The Goal: Build. Ship. Iterate.

The first step to building anything real is having the right tools. We’re not about theoretical setups; we’re about a development environment that lets you write good code and ship it fast.

Many learning platforms use in-browser editors. They’re fine for a quick start, but they don’t build real-world skills. We’re building the environment that mirrors professional workflows. This means installations.

Yes, installing software, editors, and even operating systems can be a pain. Embrace the friction. This is an invaluable, real-world skill that separates builders from dabblers.

Your Path to a Dev Environment

We focus on environments that work. Deviations add complexity we don’t need.

Recommended: macOS or Linux

If you’re on a Mac, you’re already in a Unix-like environment – perfect. A few key installations and you’re set.

If you’re not on a Mac, Linux is your best bet. It’s free, powerful, and the environment most tools are built for. We’ll guide you through Ubuntu, a battle-tested, user-friendly distribution.

Windows Users: Your Options

Windows itself isn’t natively supported for the core development tools we’ll use. You need a Linux layer. Here are your paths:

  • Virtual Machine (Recommended for Ease): Run a Linux environment (like Ubuntu) within a program on your Windows machine. It’s like having a separate computer inside your computer. Easy to set up, risk-free to remove if it’s not for you.
  • Dual-Boot (Native Performance): Install Linux alongside Windows. You choose which OS to boot when your computer starts. Offers the best performance as Linux has full access to your hardware. Requires careful partitioning – take your time.
  • WSL2 (Advanced): The Windows Subsystem for Linux lets you run a Linux environment directly within Windows. Powerful, but can be confusing for beginners due to the blurred lines between OSs.

Chromebooks: You may be able to leverage built-in Linux support. Details in the next step.

Why This Approach?

  • Tested Environments: Our instructions are validated on macOS and Ubuntu. This minimizes troubleshooting time so you can focus on coding.
  • Community Alignment: Using recommended tools makes it easier to get support from The Rebel Alliance.
  • Tooling Native to Linux: Many critical development tools are built for or run best on Linux.
  • Professional Standard: Most developers use Unix-based systems. Get acquainted now.
  • Performance: Linux is lean. It uses fewer resources than Windows, making it ideal for powerful development, even on older hardware.

No Getting Around It

We can only support specific environments. Native Windows is not supported for development. This isn’t a limitation; it’s a deliberate choice to ensure you have the smoothest path to shipping code. Stick to macOS, Ubuntu, or a Linux environment via VM/dual-boot/WSL2.

The goal is to get you building and shipping, not wrestling with incompatible tools. Let’s get your environment ship-shape.

—FILE: Installations.md—

Installations | The Rebellion Method

Your Dev Environment: Ship-Ready

Get Set Up: The Rebellion Way

If you’re on macOS, Ubuntu, or an official Ubuntu flavor, and have Google Chrome installed, you can likely skip the heavy lifting. Otherwise, let’s build your battle station.

The Goal: A robust development environment that lets you build and ship fast. We use tools that mirror professional workflows.

Choosing Your Weapon: Operating System Setup

We support environments built for development.

  • macOS: Unix-based and great for development. A few installs and you’re ready.
  • Linux (Ubuntu Recommended): Free, powerful, and the standard for many tools. We guide you through Ubuntu.

Windows Users: Your Path

Windows isn’t natively supported for our core tools. You need a Linux layer:

  • Virtual Machine (Recommended): Run Ubuntu inside Windows. Easiest, safest way to start.
  • Dual-Boot: Install Ubuntu alongside Windows. Native performance, but requires disk partitioning. Proceed with care.
  • WSL2 (Advanced): Linux environment within Windows. Powerful, but can be complex for beginners.

Chromebooks: Built-in Linux support is viable. Details follow.

Why Google Chrome?

It’s the de facto browser standard, with powerful developer tools essential for inspecting, debugging, and testing your sites. Our instructions and examples are based on Chrome.

Your Assignment

  1. Environment Setup (if needed):
    • Virtual Machine: Easiest. Get Ubuntu running within Windows/macOS.
    • Dual-Boot: Install Ubuntu alongside your existing OS.
    • ChromeOS/Flex: For Chromebooks.
    • WSL2: For advanced Windows users. (Follow the specific guides for your chosen setup.)
  2. Browser Setup: Install Google Chrome. Our documentation and examples assume you’re using it.

Unsupported: We don’t support Raspberry Pi or other niche devices. Stick to standard desktops/laptops.

Focus: Get your environment configured correctly. This smooths the path for all subsequent learning. If you’re not on macOS or Ubuntu, choose ONE setup option and follow it precisely.

—FILE: Text Editors.md—

Text Editors | The Rebellion Method

Your Primary Weapon: The Code Editor

Code Like a Pro, Not a Word Processor

You’ll spend more time in your text editor than almost anywhere else. A good one isn’t just for typing; it’s a force multiplier that helps you write cleaner, faster, error-free code.

Why not Microsoft Word? Word and similar “rich text” editors embed formatting information within your files. Code editors, on the other hand, handle plain text – exactly what computers need to read and execute your code. No hidden formatting, just pure instructions.

The Code Editor Advantage

Think of code editors as specialized command centers. They are designed for developers and come packed with features that streamline your workflow:

  • Syntax Highlighting: Makes code readable by coloring different elements.
  • Real-time Error Checking (Linting): Catches syntax errors and style issues as you type.
  • Auto-formatting: Keeps your code clean and consistent.
  • Bracket/Brace Matching: Prevents those maddening “missing bracket” bugs.
  • Extensibility: Tons of plugins and extensions to customize your environment.

Your Tool of Choice: VS Code

We standardize on Visual Studio Code (VS Code). It’s free, powerful, has excellent community support, and integrates seamlessly with essential tools like Git.

Why VS Code?

  • Free & Cross-Platform: Works the same everywhere.
  • Massive Extension Ecosystem: Tailor it to your needs.
  • Industry Standard: Widely used by developers globally.
  • Great Git Integration: Essential for version control.

Important: If you’re using a Virtual Machine for Linux, install VS Code inside the VM. This ensures your development environment is self-contained.

Getting VS Code Set Up

Follow the specific instructions for your operating system:

(Note: The following instructions are simplified examples. Refer to the official VS Code documentation for the most current and detailed guidance for your specific OS.)

Linux (Ubuntu/Debian-based)

  1. Download: 
    wget -O code-latest.deb 'https://code.visualstudio.com/sha/download?build=stable&os=linux-deb-x64'
  2. Install: 
    sudo apt install ./code-latest.deb
  3. Clean up: 
    rm code-latest.deb
  4. Launch: From the terminal, type code or find it in your application menu.

(Optional: Add Microsoft’s repository for automatic updates.)

macOS

  1. Download: Get the universal installer from the VS Code website.
  2. Install: Unzip the downloaded file and drag Visual Studio Code.app to your Applications folder.
  3. Clean up: Delete the downloaded zip file.
  4. Launch: From your Applications folder.

Windows

  1. Download & Install: Follow the standard Windows installation from the VS Code website.
  2. Clean up: Delete the installer file.
  3. WSL2 Integration: If using WSL2, ensure you install the WSL extension within VS Code. Open a WSL2 terminal and run code to verify it launches correctly within your Linux environment.

Your Mission

Familiarize yourself with VS Code. Watch a beginner tutorial focusing on its interface and core features. Don’t get bogged down; just get a feel for the tool.

AI Note: VS Code often comes with AI code completion features (like Copilot). While AI is powerful, we’ll address its role specifically. For now, disable any AI code completion features that might nudge you toward shortcuts without understanding. We build skills first.

—FILE: Command Line Basics.md—

Command Line Basics | The Rebellion Method

Master Your Machine: Navigate and Control

Why the Command Line? It’s Your Command Center.

Forget the hacker movie tropes. The command line interface (CLI) is your direct link to the computer’s core functions. It’s where you’ll run programs, manage files, and execute powerful commands – efficiently.

Yes, it has its own language, but the commands you’ll use 95% of the time are simple and become second nature quickly. This isn’t optional; it’s essential for a developer.

What You’ll Conquer

  • Opening the Terminal: Your gateway to the CLI.
  • Navigation: Move through directories (folders) like a pro.
  • File & Directory Manipulation: Create, rename, move, and delete files and folders directly.
  • Launching Programs: Open files and applications from the command line.

Your Terminal Toolkit

  • Linux: Search for “Terminal” or press Ctrl + Alt + T.
  • macOS: Use Spotlight (Cmd + Space) and search for “Terminal”, or find it in Applications > Utilities.

You’ll see a prompt – usually ending in $ or %. This is where you type commands.

$ whoami (Type this and press Enter) This will show your username. Simple, effective.

Tip: Commands are often shown with the prompt, like $ command. Don’t type the $.

Work Like a Rebel: Efficiency Hacks

  1. Smart Copy/Paste: Use Ctrl + Shift + C (Cmd + C on Mac) to copy and Ctrl + Shift + V (Cmd + V on Mac) to paste inside the terminal.
  2. Tab Completion: This is critical. Start typing a command or path, hit Tab, and the CLI will autocomplete if there’s only one option, or show you the possibilities if there are multiple. This saves massive amounts of typing and prevents errors.
    • Example: cd Doc + Tab might show Documents/ and Downloads/. Type cd Docu + Tab and it will complete Documents/.
  3. Current Directory Shortcut (.): Use code . (assuming VS Code is installed and in your PATH) to open the current directory and all its files in VS Code. It’s a massive time-saver for project management.

Essential Commands to Practice

Start by creating a basic web project structure.

  1. Create a project directory: mkdir my-first-site
  2. Move into it: cd my-first-site
  3. Create essential files: touch index.html style.css script.js
  4. Create an image folder: mkdir images
  5. Check your work: ls (Lists the contents of the current directory)

This simple sequence is the foundation for most web projects. Practice it until it’s muscle memory.

Knowledge Check

  • What is the command line?
  • How do you open the command line on your computer?
  • How can you navigate to a particular directory?
  • What does cd .. do?
  • How do you display the name of the current directory?
  • How do you display the contents of the current directory?
  • How do you create a new directory?
  • How do you create a new file?
  • How do you destroy a directory or file?
  • How do you rename a directory or file?

—FILE: Introduction to Git.md—

Introduction to Git | The Rebellion Method

Version Control: Your Project’s Time Machine

Git: The Ultimate Save Button

Imagine a “save” button for your entire project – not just one file, but all your files, at any point in time. That’s Git. It’s a version control system that tracks every change you make.

Why not just copy files? MyProject-v1.doc, MyProject-v2-final.doc, MyProject-final-really.doc… Sound familiar? This is chaotic and error-prone.

Git records differences between saves (called “commits”) and maintains a complete history. This means:

  • Effortless Rollbacks: Made a mistake? Revert to any previous state instantly.
  • Project Evolution: See exactly how your project grew over time.
  • Collaboration: Work with others seamlessly, merging changes without stepping on toes.

Git vs. GitHub: Know the Difference

  • Git: The tool itself. It runs on your local machine to manage versions.
  • GitHub: A service (like Google Drive for code) that hosts your Git repositories online. It’s for backup, collaboration, and showcasing your work. We use GitHub because it’s the industry standard.

Why This Matters Now

Mastering Git isn’t just about saving files. It’s foundational for:

  • Independent Building: Track your own progress, revert mistakes, and learn from your project’s history.
  • Teamwork: Essential for collaborative development in any professional setting.
  • Portfolio: Your GitHub profile is your developer resume.

Your Mission

  1. Understand Version Control: Grasp the core concept of tracking changes over time.
  2. Git vs. Text Editor: Recognize that Git saves changes and history, not just static files.
  3. Individual & Team Power: Understand why Git is indispensable for both solo projects and team collaboration.

The next steps will get you hands-on with Git commands. This is where the real power unlocks.

—FILE: Git Basics.md—

Git Basics | The Rebellion Method

Workflow Essentials: Commit, Stage, Push

Your Essential Git Commands

This is your core Git toolkit – the commands you’ll use 80% of the time. Master these, and you’ve got Git licked.

Your First Repository

  1. Create a GitHub Repo:
    • Go to GitHub. Create a new repository named git-test.
    • Crucially: Enable “Add a README file”.
    • Click “Create repository”.
  2. Get the SSH URL: On your new repo page, click the green “Code” button. Select SSH, then copy the URL (it looks like git@github.com:YourUsername/git-test.git).
  3. Local Setup:
    • Open your terminal.
    • Create a directory for all your projects: mkdir repos
    • Navigate into it: cd repos
  4. Clone: Bring the repository to your machine: git clone git@github.com:YourUsername/git-test.git (Replace YourUsername with your actual GitHub username)
  5. Verify: Navigate into the cloned directory (cd git-test) and run git remote -v. You should see your GitHub repository listed.

The Git Workflow: Snapshots of Your Code

This is the cycle: Stage -> Commit -> Push.

  1. Create a File: Inside your git-test directory, create a file: touch hello_world.txt
  2. Check Status: See what Git knows about your files: git status (You’ll see hello_world.txt listed in red as “Untracked”)
  3. Stage Changes: Add the file to Git’s “waiting room” for the next commit: git add hello_world.txt
  4. Check Status Again: git status (hello_world.txt should now be green, listed under “Changes to be committed”)
  5. Commit: Take a snapshot. The -m flag adds a message describing the change: git commit -m "Add hello_world.txt" (This saves the snapshot locally.)
  6. Check Log: View your commit history: git log (You’ll see your commit listed.)

Modify and Re-Commit

  1. Edit: Open README.md in VS Code (code . in the terminal, then open README.md). Add “Hello Rebellion!” and save.
  2. Check Status: git status (README.md will be red, under “Changes not staged for commit”)
  3. Stage: git add README.md
  4. Stage All: (A common shortcut) git add . (Adds all modified/new files in the current directory and subdirectories)
  5. Check Status: Everything should be green.
  6. Commit: git commit -m "Edit README.md and hello_world.txt"

Ship It: Push to GitHub

  1. Upload: Send your local commits to GitHub: git push origin main (Assuming your default branch is main. If you get errors about authentication, double-check your SSH key setup.)
  2. Final Check: Run git status. It should say you’re up-to-date. Refresh your GitHub repo page – you’ll see your changes.

Rule: Never edit directly on GitHub. Always work locally, commit, and then push.

Essential Commands Cheat Sheet

  • Clone: git clone [ssh_url]
  • Status: git status
  • Add: git add . (stage all) or git add [file]
  • Commit: git commit -m "Your descriptive message"
  • Push: git push origin main
  • Log: git log
  • Remote: git remote -v

—FILE: Setting up Git.md—

Setting up Git | The Rebellion Method

Your Digital ID: Git & GitHub Configuration

Git & GitHub: Your Version Control Foundation

  • Git: The local version control system. It tracks changes on your machine.
  • GitHub: The remote hosting service. Stores your Git repositories online for backup and collaboration.

They sound similar, but they’re distinct. We use GitHub because it’s the standard.

Step 1: Install Git

Ensure you have a recent version.

Linux (Ubuntu)

  1. Update System: 
    sudo apt update
sudo apt upgrade
  2. Install Git: 
    sudo apt install git
  3. Verify Version: Check if it’s 2.28 or higher: 
    git --version

    (If too old, add the PPA: sudo add-apt-repository ppa:git-core/ppa, then sudo apt update && sudo apt install git)

macOS

  1. Install Homebrew: If you don’t have it, open Terminal and run: 
    /bin/bash -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/install/HEAD/install.sh)"

    (Follow any on-screen prompts, especially for adding Homebrew to your PATH on Apple Silicon).

  2. Install Git: 
    brew install git
  3. Verify Version: Open a new terminal window and run: 
    git --version

    (Ensure it’s 2.28+)

    (Troubleshooting: Run brew doctor and follow its instructions if you hit errors.)

Step 2: Configure Your Identity

Git needs to know who you are for your commits.

  1. GitHub Account: Create one at GitHub.com.
    • Privacy: In GitHub settings > Emails, enable “Keep my email addresses private” and “Block command line email from appearing on public contributions”. Use the provided private email address for Git configuration.
  2. Configure Git: Open your terminal and run these commands, replacing placeholders with your actual name and private GitHub email: 
    git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "your_private_github_email@users.noreply.github.com"
  3. Set Default Branch: Ensure new local repositories default to main: 
    git config --global init.defaultBranch main
  4. Configure Pull Behavior: 
    git config --global pull.rebase false
  5. Verify Configuration: 
    git config --get user.name
git config --get user.email

    (Output should match your name and private email)

macOS Specific: Ignore .DS_Store files

Prevent these system files from cluttering your Git history:

echo .DS_Store >> ~/.gitignore_global
git config --global core.excludesfile ~/.gitignore_global

Step 3: SSH Key for Secure Access

This lets you interact with GitHub without passwords.

  1. Check for Existing Key: 
    ls ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub

    (If you see a file path, you likely have a key. If you get “No such file…”, proceed to create one.)

  2. Create New SSH Key: 
    ssh-keygen -t ed25519
    • Press Enter to accept the default save location.
    • Enter a strong passphrase (recommended for security) or press Enter for no passphrase.
  3. Copy Public Key: 
    cat ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub
    • Copy the entire output (starts with ssh-ed25519...).
  4. Add Key to GitHub:
    • Go to GitHub > Settings > SSH and GPG keys.
    • Click “New SSH Key”.
    • Paste your copied key into the “Key” field.
    • Give it a descriptive title (e.g., “My Laptop”).
    • Click “Add SSH Key”.
  5. Test Connection: 
    ssh -T git@github.com
    • If prompted about authenticity, type yes.
    • You should see: Hi YourUsername! You’ve successfully authenticated, but GitHub does not provide shell access.

You’ve set up your Git environment. This is a critical step. Well done, Rebel.

Master the Fundamentals, Build with Confidence

Introduction

Before you can build the web, you need to understand how it works. This isn’t about rote memorization; it’s about building a solid foundation so you can confidently navigate the digital landscape and speak the language of the web.

What You’ll Master:

  • The Internet: What it is and how it moves data.
  • Packets: The building blocks of online communication.
  • Core Components: Web pages, servers, browsers, and search engines – demystified.
  • Clients & Servers: Understanding the fundamental interaction.
  • IP Addresses & DNS: How machines find each other.
  • Routers & ISPs: The infrastructure that makes it all possible.

—FILE: Introduction to HTML and CSS.md—

Introduction to HTML and CSS | The Rebellion

Build the Skeleton, Style the Soul

Introduction

It’s time to build. This is where you learn the core languages of the web: HTML and CSS. With these, you’ll create the structure and the look of everything you see online.

What You’ll Master:

  • HTML: The structure and content of your web pages.
  • CSS: The styling, layout, and visual appeal.
  • Synergy: How HTML and CSS work together seamlessly.

HTML and CSS: The Dynamic Duo

HTML provides the raw content – the text, the images, the links. CSS takes that raw content and makes it sing – positioning elements, adding color, choosing fonts, and creating a polished look.

While some call them ‘programming languages,’ technically, they are markup and styling languages. They define what is on the page and how it looks, not the logic that makes it do things. That’s JavaScript’s domain, which you’ll conquer next. But for now, master HTML and CSS. They are your essential toolkit.

Your Mission: Knowledge Check

  • What do HTML and CSS stand for?
  • Which language do you use for putting paragraphs of text on a webpage?
  • Which language do you use for changing the font and background color of an element?
  • What is the fundamental difference between HTML, CSS, and JavaScript?

—FILE: Elements and Tags.md—

Elements and Tags | The Rebellion

The Building Blocks of Web Content

Introduction

HTML is how we define the structure and content of every webpage – the paragraphs, the headings, the lists, the images, the links. This lesson breaks down the fundamental HTML elements and tags.

What You’ll Master:

  • HTML Tags: The syntax that defines elements.
  • HTML Elements: How tags wrap content to create meaningful structures.

Elements and Tags: Structure Defined

Think of HTML tags as containers for your content.

  • Opening Tags: These signal the start of an element. They look like <tagname>, for instance <p> for a paragraph.
  • Closing Tags: These signal the end of an element. They look like </tagname>, for instance </p>.
  • Content: Everything between the opening and closing tags is the content of that element.

A complete paragraph element looks like this:

<p>This is a paragraph.</p>
  • <p>: The opening tag.
  • This is a paragraph.: The content.
  • </p>: The closing tag.

The browser uses these tags to understand and display your content. Using the right tags – known as semantic HTML – is crucial for search engine optimization and accessibility. It tells browsers and assistive technologies exactly what kind of content they’re dealing with.

Void Elements: The Exceptions

Some elements don’t wrap content and don’t need a closing tag. These are void elements, like <br> (line break) or <img> (image). They stand alone. You might see them written with a trailing slash (e.g., <br />), but modern HTML5 considers this unnecessary.

Your Mission: Knowledge Check

  • What is an HTML tag?
  • What are the three essential parts of a standard HTML element?
  • What are void elements, and how do they differ from regular HTML elements?

—FILE: HTML Boilerplate.md—

HTML Boilerplate | The Rebellion

The Essential Framework for Every Web Page

Introduction

Every HTML document needs a consistent starting structure, or boilerplate. This lesson covers the essential components that form the backbone of any HTML file. Get this right, and you’re ready to build.

What You’ll Master:

  • The Basic Structure: Essential elements for any HTML document.
  • Viewing Your Work: How to open your HTML files in a browser.

Creating Your First HTML File

  1. Create a folder for your project, name it my-first-site.
  2. Inside, create a file named index.html. We use index.html as the default filename for the homepage of any website. Servers look for it automatically.

The Core Components:

The <!DOCTYPE html> Declaration

This is the very first line. It tells the browser that your document is using the latest standard: HTML5. Always use it.

The <html> Element

This is the root element. Everything else lives inside it. We also add the lang attribute here to specify the document’s language (e.g., lang="en" for English), which is vital for accessibility, helping screen readers pronounce text correctly.

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
  <!-- Content goes here -->
</html>

The <head> Element

This section contains meta-information about your page – things the browser needs but aren’t directly displayed to the user.

  • <meta charset="UTF-8">: Crucial for displaying special characters and various languages correctly. Always include this.
  • <title>: This is the text that appears in the browser tab. Give your page a clear, meaningful title.
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
  <head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <title>My Awesome Webpage</title>
  </head>
  <!-- Body content goes here -->
</html>

The <body> Element

This is where all the visible content of your webpage goes: text, images, links, everything the user sees.

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
  <head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <title>My Awesome Webpage</title>
  </head>
  <body>
    <!-- Your visible content here -->
  </body>
</html>

Pro-Tip: In VS Code, type ! and press Enter to auto-generate this boilerplate instantly. Use it, but also practice writing it manually to build muscle memory.

Viewing Your HTML in the Browser

  • Drag and Drop: Drag your index.html file directly into your browser window.
  • Double Click: Double-click the file in your file explorer.
  • Terminal Command: Use open index.html (macOS) or explorer.exe index.html (WSL) in your terminal.

Add an <h1>Hello World!</h1> inside the <body> section, save, and refresh your browser to see it appear.

Your Mission: Knowledge Check

  • What is the purpose of the <!DOCTYPE html> declaration?
  • What is the fundamental role of the <html> element?
  • What kind of information goes inside the <head> element, and what goes inside the <body> element?

—FILE: Working with Text.md—

Working with Text | The Rebellion

Crafting Content: Paragraphs, Headings, and Emphasis

Introduction

Most of the web is text. This lesson covers the essential HTML elements for structuring and emphasizing textual content.

What You’ll Master:

  • Paragraphs: Creating distinct blocks of text.
  • Headings: Structuring your content hierarchy.
  • Emphasis: Making text bold (<strong>) and italic (<em>).
  • Nesting: Understanding parent-child relationships.
  • Comments: Leaving notes in your code.

Essential Text Elements:

Paragraphs (<p>)

Browsers ignore new lines in HTML. To create separate paragraphs, wrap your text in <p> tags.

<p>This is the first paragraph.</p>
<p>This is the second paragraph.</p>

Headings (<h1> to <h6>)

Headings define the structure and importance of your content. <h1> is the main heading, with <h6> being the least important. Use them logically to build a clear content hierarchy.

<h1>Main Page Title</h1>
<h2>Section Title</h2>
<h3>Subsection Title</h3>

Bold and Important Text (<strong>)

Use <strong> to wrap text that is semantically important. This makes it bold and signals its significance to browsers and screen readers.

<p>This is a normal paragraph, but <strong>this word is very important</strong>.</p>

Italicized and Emphasized Text (<em>)

Use <em> to add emphasis to text. This can affect screen reader tone and visually italicizes the text.

<p>This is a normal sentence, but <em>this part is emphasized</em>.</p>

Nesting and Indentation

Elements can be placed inside other elements. The outer element is the parent, and the inner ones are children. Sibling elements are at the same nesting level. Indentation makes this structure clear and readable – use it consistently (e.g., two spaces per level).

<body>
  <p>This is a paragraph (child of body).</p>
  <p>This is another paragraph (sibling to the first).</p>
</body>

HTML Comments (<!-- -->)

Comments are notes for humans; they are ignored by the browser. Use them to explain complex code or leave reminders.

<!-- This is a comment. It won't show on the page. -->

VS Code Shortcut: Use Cmd + / (Mac) or Ctrl + / (Windows/Linux) to quickly comment or uncomment lines.

Your Mission: Hands-on Practice

Create a simple blog post structure using headings, paragraphs, and apply <strong> and <em> to various parts of the text. Use Lorem ipsum text for practice content.

Your Mission: Knowledge Check

  • How do you create distinct paragraphs in HTML?
  • How do you create headings, and what is the significance of heading levels?
  • What is the difference between using <strong> and <em>?
  • Explain the parent-child and sibling relationships between HTML elements.
  • How do you write a comment in HTML?

—FILE: Lists.md—

Lists | The Rebellion

Organize Information: Ordered and Unordered Lists

Introduction

Lists are fundamental for presenting information clearly. This lesson covers how to create both unordered (bulleted) and ordered (numbered) lists in HTML.

What You’ll Master:

  • Unordered Lists (<ul>): For items where order doesn’t matter.
  • Ordered Lists (<ol>): For items where sequence is crucial.
  • List Items (<li>): The building blocks for all lists.

Creating Lists:

Unordered Lists (<ul>)

Use <ul> for lists where the sequence of items is flexible (e.g., shopping lists, features). Each item is defined with <li>.

<ul>
  <li>Item 1: Bullet points</li>
  <li>Item 2</li>
  <li>Item 3</li>
</ul>

Ordered Lists (<ol>)

Use <ol> for lists where the order is important (e.g., instructions, rankings). Each item is still defined with <li>, but the browser automatically numbers them.

<ol>
  <li>First step: Do this.</li>
  <li>Second step: Then do that.</li>
  <li>Third step: Finish up.</li>
</ol>

Your Mission: Build Your Lists

Create an HTML file and implement the following:

  1. An unordered list of your favorite programming languages.
  2. An ordered list of the steps to make your favorite beverage.
  3. An unordered list of your top 3 go-to websites for learning.
  4. An ordered list of reasons why building websites is awesome.

Your Mission: Knowledge Check

  • What HTML element creates an unordered list?
  • What HTML element creates an ordered list?
  • What HTML element is used for individual items within any type of list?

—FILE: Links and Images.md—

Links and Images | The Rebellion

Connect Your World: Navigating with Links, Enhancing with Images

Introduction

Links are the connective tissue of the web. Images add visual appeal and convey information instantly. This lesson teaches you how to implement both effectively.

What You’ll Master:

  • Links (<a>): Connecting to other pages and resources.
  • Absolute vs. Relative Links: Navigating within your site and beyond.
  • Images (<img>): Embedding visuals into your pages.
  • Essential Attributes: href, target, rel, src, alt, width, height.

Creating Links (<a> element):

Links are made using the <a> (anchor) element. The destination is specified using the href attribute.

<a href="https://www.example.com">Visit Example.com</a>
  • href: The URL or file path the link points to.
  • target="_blank": Opens the link in a new tab.
  • rel="noopener noreferrer": Crucial for security when using target="_blank". It prevents the new page from potentially manipulating your original page (tabnabbing). Always include this for safety.

Absolute vs. Relative Links

  • Absolute Links: Full URLs, including the scheme (https://) and domain (e.g., https://www.google.com). Use these for external sites.

  • Relative Links: Paths relative to your current file (e.g., about.html, ./pages/contact.html, ../images/logo.png). Use these for pages and assets within your own website.

    • ./: Current directory.
    • ../: Parent directory (one level up).

Embedding Images (<img> element):

Images are added using the <img> element. It’s a void element (no closing tag needed).

<img src="path/to/your/image.jpg" alt="Description of the image" width="300" height="200">
  • src: The path (absolute or relative) to the image file.
  • alt: Essential! Provides alternative text for screen readers and if the image fails to load. Describe the image concisely.
  • width & height: Specify dimensions to prevent layout shifts as the image loads. Use the image’s actual pixel dimensions.

Image Formats: Common web formats include JPEG, PNG, GIF, and SVG. Choose based on your needs (photos vs. graphics, transparency).

Important: Always use images you have the rights to use. Check licenses and provide attribution where required. Use Google’s “Usage rights: Creative Commons” filter when searching for images.

Your Mission: Build a Multi-Page Site

  1. Create a main index.html file. Add an <h1> with your name.
  2. Create an about.html file. Add an <h1> with “About Me”.
  3. In index.html, add a link to about.html using a relative path.
  4. In about.html, add a link back to index.html.
  5. Create an images folder. Download a suitable image (e.g., a picture of yourself or something relevant) and place it in the images folder as profile.jpg.
  6. Add this image to your index.html file using an <img> tag, including src, alt, width, and height attributes.
  7. Add a link to an external website (like The Rebellion’s main page) from your index.html, using target="_blank" and rel="noopener noreferrer".

Your Mission: Knowledge Check

  • What HTML element is used to create links?
  • What is the primary function of the href attribute?
  • What is the security purpose of rel="noopener noreferrer" when using target="_blank"?
  • Explain the difference between an absolute link and a relative link, providing examples.
  • Which element is used to display an image?
  • What are the two absolutely essential attributes for any <img> tag?
  • How do you navigate to a file in a parent directory using a relative path?

—FILE: Commit Messages.md—

Commit Messages | The Rebellion

Why Bother with Commits?

Let’s cut to the chase: good commit messages matter because they’re a direct signal of your professionalism and clarity. When you’re shipping real projects, your Git history is part of your public-facing work.

  • Employers look. A clean, descriptive commit history screams “I know what I’m doing.”
  • You look back. Future You will thank Present You for remembering why a change was made.
  • Collaboration is faster. If anyone else ever touches your code, good messages are the bedrock of understanding.

The Anatomy of a Good Commit

Forget the vague “fixed stuff.” A good commit message tells a story. It has two parts:

  1. Subject: A punchy, 72-character-max summary of the change. Think headline. 
    Add responsive navigation to mobile view
  2. Body: (Optional, but highly recommended) Explain the why. What problem did this solve? How did your change address it? Separate this from the subject with a blank line. 
    The previous navigation did not collapse correctly on screens smaller than 768px,
leading to usability issues. This change implements a hamburger menu pattern
that expands and collapses as expected.

When to Commit: Ship, Ship, Ship!

Think of commits as checkpoints. Every time you cross a meaningful milestone, capture it.

  • Got a feature working? Commit.
  • Fixed a stubborn bug? Commit.
  • Refactored a messy section? Commit.

Make your commits granular. A history of small, focused commits is far more valuable than a few massive, cryptic ones. Commit often, push often, and keep that momentum going.

Quick Tips

  • Use active voice: “Implement feature”, not “Feature implemented”.
  • Avoid “WIP” or “don’t commit”: If it’s in your repo, it’s potentially releasable.
  • AI is your co-pilot: Use AI to help draft messages if you’re stuck, but always review and refine. Ensure it captures the why.

—FILE: Intro to CSS.md—

Intro to CSS | The Rebellion

Style Your Sites. Fast.

HTML gives your website structure. CSS gives it style. This is where web pages go from raw content to something visually engaging. We’ll focus on the core CSS concepts you need to make things look good, quickly and confidently.

What You’ll Master:

  • Applying Styles: How to inject CSS into your HTML.
  • Targeting Elements: Using classes and IDs to precisely control which elements get styled.
  • Selectors: The powerful language you use to tell CSS what to style.

Core Concepts: The Building Blocks

CSS rules are simple: a selector points to an HTML element, and declarations (property-value pairs) dictate how it should look.

/* Selector */
.my-element {
  /* Declaration: Property: Value */
  color: hotpink;
  font-size: 16px;
}
  • div: A versatile block-level container. Often used to group elements for layout or styling.
  • span: An inline container, perfect for styling small pieces of text within a larger block.

Selectors: Pointing to Your Pixels

  • Universal Selector (*): Styles everything. Use sparingly. ```css
    • { color: purple; /* Applies purple text to all elements */ } ```
  • Type Selectors: Target all elements of a specific type (e.g., p, h1, div). 
    div {
  border: 1px solid black; /* Adds a border to all divs */
}
  • Class Selectors (.): The workhorse. Apply styles to any element with a specific class. You can use the same class on multiple elements. 
    <p class="warning-message">Something is wrong!</p>

    .warning-message {
  color: red;
}
    • Pro-Tip: Class names cannot start with a number. Use hyphens for multi-word names (e.g., alert-text, not alert text).
  • ID Selectors (#): Target a single, unique element on the page. Use IDs sparingly and only when a class won’t suffice. IDs also cannot start with a number. 
    <div id="main-header">My Awesome Site</div>

    #main-header {
  background-color: navy;
}
  • Grouping Selectors (,): Apply the same styles to multiple selectors. 
    .button, button, .submit-button {
  background-color: green;
  color: white;
}
  • Chaining Selectors: Target an element that matches multiple conditions. 
    <div class="alert urgent">System failure!</div>

    /* Targets only divs with BOTH 'alert' AND 'urgent' classes */
div.alert.urgent {
  font-weight: bold;
}
  • Descendant Combinator (space): Target an element that is nested inside another. 
    <article>
  <p>This paragraph is inside article.</p>
</article>
<p>This paragraph is not.</p>

    /* Selects only paragraphs INSIDE an article */
article p {
  color: gray;
}

Essential Properties to Ship With

  • color: Sets text color. (Accepts keywords, HEX, RGB, HSL values).
  • background-color: Sets the background of an element.
  • font-family: Specifies the typeface. List fallbacks: font-family: Arial, sans-serif;
  • font-size: Sets text size (e.g., 16px, 1.2em).
  • font-weight: Controls boldness (bold, normal, or numeric values like 700).
  • text-align: Aligns text (center, left, right).
  • height / width: Sets dimensions for elements, especially images. Use height: auto; with a specific width to maintain aspect ratio.

Adding CSS to Your HTML: Keep It Clean

  1. External CSS (Recommended): The cleanest approach. Link a separate .css file in your HTML’s <head>. 
    <!-- index.html -->
<head>
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css">
</head>

    /* styles.css */
body {
  font-family: sans-serif;
}
    • Why? Keeps HTML lean and CSS organized across multiple pages.
  2. Internal CSS: Embed styles directly in the <head> using <style> tags. 
    <head>
  <style>
    h1 { color: blue; }
  </style>
</head>
    • Use Case: Unique styles for a single page. Less maintainable for larger sites.
  3. Inline CSS: Apply styles directly to an HTML element using the style attribute. 
    <p style="color: red; font-weight: bold;">This is red and bold.</p>
    • Avoid: This is messy, hard to maintain, and overrides other styles. Use only as a last resort for single, isolated elements.

—FILE: The Cascade.md—

The Cascade | The Rebellion

When Styles Collide: The Cascade Decides

You wrote CSS. It should work. But sometimes, rules conflict. Why? The Cascade. It’s CSS’s built-in system for deciding which styles win when multiple rules target the same element. Browser defaults also play a role. Understanding the Cascade prevents CSS headaches.

The Cascade primarily uses three factors to resolve conflicts:

  1. Specificity: How targeted is the selector?
  2. Inheritance: Do child elements inherit properties from parents?
  3. Rule Order: Which rule came last in the CSS?

Specificity: The Tie-Breaker

More specific rules override less specific ones. Here’s the hierarchy:

  1. Inline Styles: Highest specificity (rarely the right choice for anything complex).
  2. ID Selectors (#): Very specific.
  3. Class Selectors (.), Attribute Selectors, Pseudo-classes: Medium specificity.
  4. Type Selectors (p, div), Universal Selector (*), Combinators (space, >, +, ~): Lowest specificity.
  • Analogy: Think of it like a competition. An ID is a star athlete. A class is a strong team. A type selector is just a participant.
  • Tie-breaker within a level: If two rules have the same highest specificity level (e.g., both use class selectors), the one with more selectors of that type wins. Rule .main .content is more specific than .content.

Example:

<div class="main">
  <p class="content alert">This text is red.</p>
</div>

/* Rule 1: Low specificity (type + class) */
.content { color: blue; }

/* Rule 2: Higher specificity (two classes) */
.main .content { color: red; }

Rule 2 wins because it uses more class selectors.

Important: Universal selectors (*) and combinators (spaces, >) do not add to specificity.

Inheritance: Passing Down Styles

Certain properties (like color, font-family, font-size) are inherited by child elements. If you set color: blue; on a div, all text inside that div will be blue unless a more specific rule overrides it.

  • Check MDN: You can determine if a property is inherited in its documentation.
  • Direct Targeting Wins: A rule directly targeting a child element (even with lower specificity) overrides inherited styles.

Example:

<div id="parent">
  <p class="child">This text is blue.</p>
</div>

/* Rule 1: High specificity ID, but style is inherited */
#parent { color: red; }

/* Rule 2: Lower specificity class, but directly targets the element */
.child { color: blue; }

The .child rule wins because it directly targets the p element.

Rule Order: Last Rule Wins

If specificity and inheritance can’t decide, the rule that appears last in your CSS file wins. This is the final tie-breaker.

Example:

.message { color: yellow; }
.message { color: green; } /* This one wins */

When building, aim for clear specificity. Relying on the cascade order or inheritance alone can lead to complex, hard-to-debug CSS.

—FILE: Inspecting HTML and CSS.md—

Inspecting HTML and CSS | The Rebellion

Debug Like a Pro: The Inspector is Your Best Friend

Frontend development is iterative. You build, you test, you tweak. The browser’s developer tools, specifically the inspector, are your essential toolkit for understanding and debugging your live code. Forget guessing; inspect and know.

Accessing the Inspector

  • Right-click any element on a webpage and select “Inspect”.
  • Or, press F12.

Focus on the Elements and Styles panels for now.

Inspecting Elements: Pinpointing the Target

  1. Elements Panel: Shows your page’s HTML structure like a tree. Click any element here to select it.
  2. Element Select Tool: (Look for an arrow icon, usually top-left in the inspector). Click this, then hover over any element on the page itself. This is often faster than digging through the Elements tree.

Understanding Styles: What’s Actually Applied?

Once an element is selected:

  • Styles Panel: This is gold. It lists all CSS rules currently affecting the selected element.
    • Active Styles: These are applied.
    • Strikethrough Styles: These are being overridden by a more specific or later rule. This is crucial for debugging conflicts!

Testing CSS in Real-Time: Experiment Fearlessly

The inspector isn’t just for looking; it’s for doing.

  1. Edit Existing Properties: Click directly on a property value (e.g., color: blue;) and type in a new value (color: red;). The page updates instantly.
  2. Add New Properties: Click within a selector’s block (e.g., between { and }) and start typing a new property (margin-top). The inspector will offer suggestions.
  3. Try New Selectors: You can even add entirely new rules in the Styles panel to see how they’d affect the page.

Crucial Note: Changes made in the inspector are temporary. They disappear on page refresh. This is fantastic for rapid experimentation but remember to copy your successful tweaks back into your actual code files.

—FILE: The Box Model.md—

The Box Model | The Rebellion

Every Element is a Box. Master Them.

Understand this: every single HTML element is a rectangular box. Layout and positioning in CSS boil down to arranging these boxes. The Box Model is your fundamental concept for controlling their size and spacing.

The Anatomy of a Box

From inside out, a box consists of:

  1. Content: The actual text, image, or other element data.
  2. Padding: Space between the content and the border. It adds space inside the box.
  3. Border: A line surrounding the padding and content.
  4. Margin: Space outside the border, separating this box from adjacent elements.

Visualizing it:

+---------------------+
|       Margin        |
|  +---------------+  |
|  |    Padding    |  |
|  |  +---------+  |  |
|  |  | Content |  |  |
|  |  +---------+  |  |
|  +---------------+  |
+---------------------+

Key Properties

  • padding: Pushes content away from the border.
    • Example: padding: 15px; (applies to all sides)
    • Example: padding: 10px 20px; (10px top/bottom, 20px left/right)
  • border: Adds a visible line. Requires width, style, and color.
    • Example: border: 2px solid black;
  • margin: Pushes the entire box away from other boxes.
    • Example: margin: 10px; (applies to all sides)
    • Example: margin-top: 5px; (specific side)
    • margin: auto;: A powerful technique for horizontally centering block-level elements.

box-sizing: Controlling the Box Calculation

By default (box-sizing: content-box), padding and border add to the element’s total width and height. This can be confusing.

The alternative, and often preferred, method is box-sizing: border-box;. With this, padding and border are included within the element’s defined width and height.

Recommendation: Apply box-sizing: border-box; globally to simplify layout calculations.

/* Apply to all elements */
*, *::before, *::after {
  box-sizing: border-box;
}

Spacing Decisions

  • More space inside an element (between content and border)? Use padding.
  • More space between two separate elements? Use margin.
  • Overlap elements? Negative margins can achieve this, but use with caution.

Mastering the Box Model is non-negotiable for effective CSS layout.

—FILE: Block and Inline.md—

Block and Inline | The Rebellion

Flow Control: Block vs. Inline Elements

How do elements behave on the page by default? That’s determined by their display property: block or inline. Understanding this is key to predictable layout.

Block Elements: Full Width, New Lines

  • Default display: block;
  • Take up the full available width.
  • Always start on a new line.

  • Respect width, height, margin, and padding on all sides.

  • Common Examples: <div>, <h1>-<h6>, <p>, <ul>, <ol>, <li>, <form>, <section>, <article>

Inline Elements: In the Flow

  • Default display: inline;
  • Only take up as much width as their content needs.
  • Do not start on a new line; they flow alongside other inline elements.
  • width and height properties do not apply.

  • margin and padding only apply horizontally (left/right). Vertical margin/padding (top/bottom) are ignored or behave unexpectedly.

  • Common Examples: <a>, <span>, <strong>, <em>, <img> (note: images are a bit special, often treated like inline-block)

The Hybrid: Inline-Block

  • display: inline-block;
  • Behaves like an inline element in that it flows with text and doesn’t force a new line.
  • BUT, it behaves like a block element regarding width, height, margin, and padding on all sides.
  • A useful middle ground, but often flexbox (coming later) is a more powerful tool for complex layouts.

Generic Containers: <div> and <span>

These are your versatile, context-free boxes:

  • <div>: A block-level container. Use it to group other elements for structural purposes, layout, or targeted styling. It divides your page.
  • <span>: An inline-level container. Use it to apply styles to a small piece of text or an inline element without disrupting the flow. It’s a generic span of content.

Normal Flow

This is the default way elements are arranged on a page based on their HTML order and block/inline display types. We manipulate this flow with CSS, but understanding the default is the first step.

—FILE: Project Recipes.md—

Project: Recipes | The Rebellion

Ship Your First Static Site

It’s time to build. You’ve learned HTML; now prove it by creating a functional, multi-page static website. This project focuses purely on HTML structure – we’ll style it later.

Project Setup: Your Command Center

  1. Create Repo: On GitHub, make a new repository named rebellion-recipes.
  2. Clone Locally: git clone git@github.com:YOUR_USERNAME/rebellion-recipes.git into your repos directory. cd into it.
  3. README: Create a README.md file. Briefly describe the project – a collection of recipes. Commit this change.

Commit Strategy: Ship Early, Ship Often

  • Atomic Commits: Each commit should represent a single, logical change.
  • Descriptive Messages: Use the Subject/Body format we’ve practiced.
  • Frequency: Commit after every meaningful step – adding a new page, structuring a recipe, adding links. Don’t wait until the end.
  • Push: Regularly push your work to the rebellion-recipes repo.

Assignment: Build the Recipe Site

Iteration 1: The Homepage

  1. Create index.html in the root of your rebellion-recipes directory.
  2. Add the basic HTML boilerplate.
  3. Add an <h1> heading: “Rebellion Recipes”.
  4. Commit.

Iteration 2: Your First Recipe Page

  1. Create a recipes directory inside rebellion-recipes.
  2. Inside recipes, create an HTML file for a recipe (e.g., lasagna.html). Use boilerplate.
  3. Add an <h1> with the recipe’s name (e.g., “The Best Lasagna”).
  4. In index.html, add a link to this recipe page: 
    <a href="recipes/lasagna.html">The Best Lasagna</a>
  5. On lasagna.html, add a “Home” link to navigate back: 
    <a href="../index.html">Home</a>
  6. Commit these changes.

Iteration 3: Recipe Content

Enhance your recipe page (lasagna.html) with:

  1. An <h1> for the recipe name.
  2. An <img> tag for a picture of the dish.
  3. An <h2> heading: “Description”. Add a paragraph or two below it.
  4. An <h2> heading: “Ingredients”. Follow with an unordered list (<ul>) of ingredients.
  5. An <h2> heading: “Steps”. Follow with an ordered list (<ol>) of cooking steps.
  6. Commit.

Iteration 4: Expand the Menu

  1. Create two more recipe pages (e.g., chili.html, cookies.html) in the recipes directory, following the same structure as Iteration 3.
  2. On index.html, add links to these new recipes.
  3. Improve Navigation: Wrap all recipe links on index.html in an unordered list (<ul>) for better structure: 
    <h1>Rebellion Recipes</h1>
<ul>
  <li><a href="recipes/lasagna.html">The Best Lasagna</a></li>
  <li><a href="recipes/chili.html">Hearty Chili</a></li>
  <li><a href="recipes/cookies.html">Chocolate Chip Cookies</a></li>
</ul>
  4. Commit.

Deploying Your Site: Go Live!

Showcase your work. GitHub Pages lets you host static sites directly from your repository.

  1. Ensure index.html is in the root: Your main page must be named index.html.
  2. Go to GitHub Repo Settings: Navigate to your rebellion-recipes repository on GitHub, click “Settings”.
  3. Pages Settings: On the left sidebar, click “Pages”.
  4. Choose Branch: Under “Deploy from a branch,” select your main branch and click “Save”.
  5. Wait: It takes a few minutes (sometimes longer) for the site to become live at https://your-username.github.io/rebellion-recipes/.

Troubleshooting:

  • Double-check index.html is in the root.
  • Ensure the correct branch (main) is selected.
  • If it doesn’t appear after an hour, try toggling the branch setting (save to ‘none’, then re-save to ‘main’).

Remember: This is about learning. Don’t compare your work to advanced examples. Focus on meeting the requirements and building your skills. If you’re stuck, ask for help in the Rebel Alliance channels!
